summary: This is an email forwarding a Wall Street Journal article about the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. It details personnel changes at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, staffing issues, and the Justice Department's response to the incident.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center; the medical examiner's preliminary finding is suicide by hanging.

events.title: Jail Staff Placed on Leave, Warden Reassigned
events.description: Two jail staffers guarding Epstein's unit were placed on leave and the warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center was reassigned as the Justice Department intensified its investigation.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: After being found unconscious in his cell with marks on his neck, Epstein was placed in the suicide-watch unit.

events.title: Barr Lifts Hiring Freeze
events.description: Attorney General William Barr lifted a Trump administration hiring freeze that had affected the Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Bureau of Prisons Loses Permanent Leader
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons has been without a permanent director since May 2018, run by acting director Hugh Hurwitz.

events.title: Death of James "Whitey" Bulger
events.description: Gangster James "Whitey" Bulger was killed by fellow inmates in a West Virginia prison; the incident is under investigation by the Justice Department's inspector general.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), lower Manhattan, New York
West Virginia prison (where James "Whitey" Bulger was killed)
keyFacts: Two jail staffers guarding Jeffrey Epstein's unit the night he died were placed on administrative leave, and the warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center was reassigned.
In the hours leading up to his death, one guard wasn't a correctional officer (though had been previously), both were working overtime, and Epstein was alone in his cell without his cellmate.
Jail officials had promised to monitor Epstein every 30 minutes and keep him with a cellmate, but these protocols were not followed.

The Bureau of Prisons was described as suffering from chronic understaffing, with a loss of about 4,000 positions since 2017, leading to practices like 'augmentation' where non-officers fill guard roles.
Epstein had been placed on suicide watch on July 23 after a prior incident but was removed days later at the request of his attorneys and after psychological evaluations.
